qas.question: What material results from chemically breaking down wood?
What's the abbreviation for medium-density fiberboard?
How is wood broken down into chips and fibers?
What type of flooring can be made from wood derivatives?
What widely-used product is almost always made of wood fibers?

context: Wood unsuitable for construction in its native form may be broken down <a2_0>mechanically<a2_0/> (into fibers or chips) or chemically (into <a0_0>cellulose<a0_0/>) and used as a raw material for other building materials, such as engineered wood, as well as chipboard, hardboard, and medium-density fiberboard (<a1_0>MDF<a1_0/>). Such wood derivatives are widely used: wood fibers are an important component of most <a4_0>paper<a4_0/>, and cellulose is used as a component of some synthetic materials. Wood derivatives can also be used for kinds of flooring, for example <a3_0>laminate<a3_0/> flooring.
